conclusion: Understanding the problem involves analyzing an acceleration-time graph for an elevator starting from rest at t=0 to find its speed at t=60s.
The graph shows acceleration increasing linearly from 0 to 2 m/s² from t=0 to t=1s.
The graph shows constant acceleration of 2 m/s² from t=1s to t=4s.
The graph shows acceleration decreasing linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 from t=4s to t=5s.
The graph shows zero acceleration (constant velocity) from t=5s to t=55s.
The graph shows acceleration decreasing linearly from 0 to -2 m/s² from t=55s to t=56s.
The graph shows constant acceleration of -2 m/s² from t=56s to t=59s.
The graph shows acceleration increasing linearly from -2 m/s² to 0 from t=59s to t=60s.
Calculate velocity change for t=0 to t=1s: Area = (1/2) × 1s × 2 m/s² = 1 m/s, Δv₁ = 1 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=1s to t=4s: Area = 3s × 2 m/s² = 6 m/s, Δv₂ = 6 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=4s to t=5s: Area = (1/2) × 1s × 2 m/s² = 1 m/s, Δv₃ = 1 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=5s to t=55s: Area = 0 (zero acceleration), Δv₄ = 0 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=55s to t=56s: Area = (1/2) × 1s × (-2 m/s²) = -1 m/s, Δv₅ = -1 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=56s to t=59s: Area = 3s × (-2 m/s²) = -6 m/s, Δv₆ = -6 m/s.
Calculate velocity change for t=59s to t=60s: Area = (1/2) × 1s × (-2 m/s²) = -1 m/s, Δv₇ = -1 m/s.
Calculate final velocity at t=60s: v(60s) = v₀ + Δv₁ + Δv₂ + Δv₃ + Δv₄ + Δv₅ + Δv₆ + Δv₇ = 0 + 1 + 6 + 1 + 0 + (-1) + (-6) + (-1) = 0 m/s.
